@Tom__Jenkins @rstats_tweets yeah I realised it was because I'd done theme_update just before.

@TheRealJimShady @rstats_tweets ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy, colour = class))+
  geom_point() +
  theme(panel.grid.minor = element_line(color = "red"))

This works for me...
@Tom__Jenkins @rstats_tweets https://t.co/85FDYNUx8c

@Tom__Jenkins @rstats_tweets That this gives an error seems linked:

ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy, colour = class))+
geom_point() +
theme(panel.grid.minor = element_line(color = "red"))

@TheRealJimShady @rstats_tweets Thanks for your speedy reply Jim but unfortunately that produces an error:

Error in get(x) : 
  object 'panel.grid.minor = element_line(colour = 'red')' not found

The original use of parse_expr() and eval_tidy() doesn't produce any errors, but still doesn't work.
@Tom__Jenkins @rstats_tweets Can't test right now, but try get(). i.e. theme_update(get(x))

Posted a question in Stack Overflow about how to parse strings as an argument to theme() in ggplot2.

Be massively grateful if you could retweet or reply if you know any solutions, thanks!

urls.title: Posit AI Blog: Deep Learning and Scientific Computing with R torch: the book
urls.description: Please allow us to introduce Deep Learning and Scientific Computing with R torch. Released in e-book format today, and available freely online, this book starts out by introducing torch basics. From there, it moves on to various deep-learning use cases. Finally, it shows how to use torch for more general topics, such as matrix computations and the Fourier Transform.

tweets.text:
3. @fumeng_yang and Maryam Hedayati show we can adjust uncertainty displays to better match subjective uncertainty w/ probability perception models https://t.co/H9RhGRKsmr

(#chi2023 honorable mention)

Originally inspired by @Birdbassador's value-suppressing uncertainty palettes https://t.co/U8Zxc7Dg1p

urls.title: Subjective Probability Correction for Uncertainty Representations
urls.description: We propose a new approach to uncertainty communication: we keep the uncertainty representation fixed, but adjust the distribution displayed to compensate for biases in people's subjective probability in decision-making. To do so, we adopt a linear-in-probit model of subjective probability and derive two corrections to a Normal distribution based on the model's intercept and slope: one correcting all right-tailed probabilities, and the other preserving the mode and one focal probability. We then conduct two experiments on U.S. demographically-representative samples. We show participants hypothetical U.S. Senate election forecasts as text or a histogram and elicit their subjective probabilities using a betting task. The first experiment estimates the linear-in-probit intercepts and slopes, and confirms the biases in participants' subjective probabilities. The second, preregistered follow-up shows participants these bias-corrected forecast distributions. We find the corrections substantia

tweets.text:
Jumping on the "yay #chi2023 papers train": my students/postdoc got 4 awesome papers in! Topics are:

- multiverse analysis in #rstats 

- measuring susceptibility to misinformation in visualizations 

- bias correction for uncertainty vis

- how analysts use #ggplot2 in practice

Tidier.jl got its first commit 2 months ago.

Today, after contributions and support from many folks in the #JuliaLang community, we are launching the Tidier organization, a group of folks dedicated to making Julia a tidier place for #rstats users.

‚ô•Ô∏èüßπ 

https://t.co/UZrDSCN7k8 https://t.co/GJE6GM0qec

urls.title: Tidier
urls.description: Making Julia a Tidier Place for R Users. Tidier has 2 repositories available. Follow their code on GitHub.
